title: Will the Justices Let Go of Abortion?
summary: Overturning Roe v. Wade wouldn't settle the issue, but it would create the possibility of a settlement.. The Supreme Court heard oral arguments Wednesday in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. On Friday, under the court's usual procedure, the justices would meet to hold a preliminary vote on their decision. A member of the majority will be assigned to write it. The court will review and amend that document and is expected to hand down its decision at the end of its term, in late June or early July.

title: America's Two-Track Jobs Recovery
summary: Memo to Ron Klain: Here are the pandemic policies that worked.. Lockdowns and other harsh government measures don't stop Covid, so why is the White House still trying to defend them? "Stronger COVID measures produce STRONGER ECONOMIC outcomes," White House chief of staff Ron Klain tweeted Wednesday. "That's why jobs, growth and economic activity are UP this year, significantly over last year."

title: Senate Confirms Biden Nominee for U.S. Sanctions Chief
summary: Brian Nelson has been confirmed as the Treasury Department's undersecretary for terrorism and financial crimes. The U.S. Senate on Thursday confirmed Brian Nelson as the Treasury Department's undersecretary for terrorism and financial crimes, a critical post for national security and foreign policy, following opposition from Senate Republicans over the administration's handling of Russia's Nord Stream 2 pipeline project.

title: Pete Buttigieg's Highway to Green Heaven
summary: The spending bill gives him new power to force CO2 cuts on states.. Progressives are grousing that the tax and spending bill passed by the House doesn't include an "enforcement mechanism" to reduce greenhouse gases. If only. The fine print grants the Biden Administration new authority to force CO2 reductions across much of the economy.

title: Ray Dalio's China Equivalence
summary: The investor's comments show why so many Americans dislike Wall Street.. American political attitudes toward China's Communist Party regime have changed dramatically in the past half-decade, and for good reason. But some on Wall Street are still living in the 1990s.

title: Boston's Eviction Ban Overreach
summary: A Massachusetts judge issues a scathing reprimand to the city.. The pandemic has led to many abuses by government, and thank heavens for the courts. On Monday a Massachusetts judge overturned Boston's rental eviction moratorium and rebuked the city's public health commission for its gross "overreach of power."

title: Son of Former Panamanian President Pleads Guilty in Odebrecht Bribery Case
summary: Luis Enrique Martinelli was charged with his brother Ricardo Alberto Martinelli, who is expected in court as early as next week. Luis Enrique Martinelli, the son of a former president of Panama, pleaded guilty on Thursday to a U.S. charge over his involvement in a bribery scheme centered on Brazil's Odebrecht SA.

title: On Health Policy, Donald Trump Beats Joe Biden Hands Down
summary: Operation Warp Speed achieved a breakthrough at low cost. Build Back Better would spend huge sums to encourage failure.. Those who want to know the difference between the Democratic and Republican philosophies of governing need only compare Joe Biden's Build Back Better health agenda with Donald Trump's Operation Warp Speed.

title: Good Reasons to Go Slow on Abortion Precedents
summary: Overturning them all at once poses risks to legal and political stability. Gradualism is a better way.. Should the Supreme Court eliminate all constitutional abortion rights? That question dominated oral argument in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization on Wednesday. Opponents of abortion have urged the court to overrule almost 50 years of precedents, including Roe v. Wade (1973) and Planned Parenthood v. Casey (1992).

title: Nvidia Can Live Without Arm
summary: Chip maker's fortunes have been soaring on its own performance, and adding a major licensing business was likely to bring more trouble than it was worth. Welcome to Big Tech, Nvidia .

title: The Supreme Court Takes Up Religious Liberty-Again
summary: Organizations that get state money shouldn't have to disavow their faith.. The Supreme Court will hear arguments next week over whether state government funding programs can discriminate against religion-the third time the court has taken up the issue in the past five years. It has already prohibited excluding religious institutions simply because they are religious institutions, but it equivocated on whether governments can deny funding that would be used for religious purposes. The justices should now make clear that all forms of religious exclusion in government funding are unacceptable.

title: Biden's Covid Quagmire
summary: He can't keep his promise to 'beat' the virus. Can he escape it before it's too late?. Candidate Joe Biden's fib was that he could "beat" a global virus. President Biden's mistake was to swallow his own whopper. Welcome to the Biden virus quagmire.

title: 'The Sea We Swim In' Review: Sell Me a Bedtime Story
summary: From advertising to news, media is driven by the creation of powerful stories. Citizens and consumers need to know how they work.. A modern company should have values, a mission statement and a philosophy, but most of all it should be in the business of storytelling. So, at least, runs 21st-century wisdom. But what if your business has just leaked millions of gallons of oil into the sea? You'll need a long-term "storytelling strategy," according to "The Sea We Swim In: How Stories Work in a Data-Driven World" by Frank Rose, a veteran tech and media reporter who teaches a Columbia University seminar on the subject for executives.Arguably, however, in this case you don't have a storytelling problem; you have an exploding-oil-rig problem.

title: In Ghislaine Maxwell Trial, Epstein House Manager Gives Glimpse of Life on Estate
summary: Prosecutors alleged that Ms. Maxwell created a culture of silence as she helped Epstein traffic and abuse young girls. summary: 'Spending on curriculum, textbooks, supplies and sundries is a small portion of school budgets.'. Mike Antonucci of the Education Intelligence Agency writing for The74Million.org, Dec. 1:

title: Grab Shares Tumble in Trading Debut After Blockbuster SPAC Deal
summary: Shares of the ride-hailing and delivery company opened 19% higher, then reversed course. Grab Holdings Ltd. 's shares lost more than one-fifth of their value on their first day of trading in New York, a blow to the Southeast Asian ride-hailing and delivery giant after its record-breaking merger with a special-purpose acquisition company.

title: 'Flee' Review: Animating an Afghan Refugee's Tale
summary: Jonas Poher Rasmussen's documentary tells the story of his friend and former classmate, who fled Afghanistan as a child in the 1980s and eventually made it to Denmark. All too often animation is presumed innocent until proved otherwise-a medium best suited to wholesome cartoons, lyrical subjects and lighthearted fun. Nothing could be further from the truth, and few films have used the technique to more powerful effect than Jonas Poher Rasmussen's "Flee."

title: 'Omicron': Greek's 'Little O' Will Loom Larger Now
summary: The new coronavirus 'variant of concern' has a deceptively diminutive name.

title: FTC Challenges Nvidia's Deal for Arm Holdings
summary: The agency alleges the semiconductor deal is anticompetitive. WASHINGTON-The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday sued to block U.S. chip supplier Nvidia Corp.'s proposed landmark takeover of semiconductor-design specialist Arm Holdings, arguing the chip-industry deal is anticompetitive.

title: 'Hand of God' Review: Maturing, Mostly Happily, in Napoli
summary: Paolo Sorrentino's latest is a semi-autobiographical coming-of-age story and a love letter to the movies. If you need further evidence that God works in mysterious ways, Paolo Sorrentino's "The Hand of God" is the place to find it, although the title may be misleading. I assumed that a religious subject plus an Italian filmmaker probably added up to a deeply serious film. Wrong, or partly wrong. This is a joyous piece of autobiography, full of unholy fun and extravagant characters fondly remembered in ravishingly beautiful images. (The cinematographer was Daria D'Antonio.) It's set in Naples, where Mr. Sorrentino was born, in the 1980s, when he came of age. God does seem to reach down into the young hero's life, at a moment that isn't just serious but tragic. Still, the intervention operates through the instrument of the peerless soccer legend Diego Maradona, who has just answered residents' prayers by arriving in town, to delirious acclaim, to play for the local team. (Italy's entry for the Academy Awards, the film is playing in select theaters, and streams on Netflix starting Dec. 15.)

title: 'Mr. A & Mr. M: The Story of A&M Records' Review: Liner Notes to a Storied Company
summary: The rise and fall of A&M Records, founded by Herb Alpert and Jerry Moss, as told by those who were there.. Herb Alpert and Jerry Moss-the title subjects of "Mr. A & Mr. M: The Story of A&M Records"-appear beside each other so amiably, so happily, such close friends almost 60 years after founding one of the more important labels in recording history, that one might suspect that this two-part documentary is not going to be about conflict, infighting or anxiety. One would be right. What distinguishes the story-and will be a reminder to some, a revelation to others-is how remarkable A&M was, in timing, conviviality and art. Even record sales.

title: 'Benedetta': Cataclysm at the Convent
summary: Paul Verhoeven tells the story of the 17th-century scandal involving a lesbian nun. Does Paul Verhoeven's "Benedetta" amount to nunsploitation or nonsploitation? Is this latest feature by the now-octogenarian filmmaker who gave us "RoboCop," "Total Recall," "Basic Instinct" and "Starship Troopers" meant only to shock, scandalize and fire flaming arrows at organized religion? Or does it have another purpose in dramatizing the circumstances of a historical event involving lesbian nuns in the 17th century? Yes to all of the above. This is a significant addition to the Verhoeven canon, meaning it's elegantly crafted, formidably well performed and as fascinating as it is lurid. (The film, playing in select theaters, will move to digital platforms on Dec. 21.)

title: 'Me and the Devil' Review: Robert Johnson's Legend Amplified
summary: This streaming production from Lantern Theater Company looks at the iconic bluesman's mythic deal with the devil. Robert Johnson's celebrity was wholly posthumous, the result of the 29 records that he cut in 1936 and 1937. An itinerant regional blues singer and guitarist born in Mississippi in 1911, he performed mainly in small towns in the Mississippi Delta, and his death at age 27 prevented him from attaining wider renown. Very little is known of his life, and it was not until 1961 that Columbia released "King of the Delta Blues Singers," an LP containing 16 of his 78 rpm sides that found its way into the hands of Eric Clapton, Bob Dylan and the Rolling Stones. Their enthusiastic response (Mr. Clapton called Johnson "the greatest blues singer who ever lived") secured his well-deserved fame at long last.

title: Stocks Finish Higher After Omicron-Driven Selloff
summary: Dow industrials post largest one-day point gain since early November. U.S. stocks jumped Thursday, continuing a tumultuous week for markets driven by uncertainty about the potential impact of the Omicron variant on public health and the economy.

title: 'Christmas Movie Magic' Review: An Early Gift
summary: A newspaper reporter heads to a small town to dig into the story of a classic holiday movie in this seasonal offering from Lifetime. Whether it's Alastair Sim in "A Christmas Carol," Bruce Willis in "Die Hard" or the sacred Jewish tradition of Chinese food and a double feature, the holidays and the cinema are inseparable. Director Robert Vaughn acknowledges such in "Christmas Movie Magic," which may not be fated to become another "It's a Wonderful Life" but does acknowledge the link between Christmas movies and Christmas spirits-of the past, the present and, if the romance works out, yuletides to come.

title: Biden Administration Issues Cybersecurity Directives for Freight and Passenger Rail
summary: The orders seek to bolster security for critical transit systems considered at high risk for attack. WASHINGTON-Nearly all U.S. freight and passenger rail systems will be required to report certain cybersecurity incidents to the Department of Homeland Security within 24 hours of discovery under new directives published Thursday by the Biden administration.

summary: Sharing a name with the late Saturday Night Live comedian prepared one writer for a new world of mixed-up online identities. I'm the real Chris Farley.

summary: The Fed chief sticks to untested new policy tools while inflation transforms the American economy.. Central bankers jealously defend their credibility, one of the most powerful tools they possess to influence markets. How remarkable then that this week it took Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell less than a minute to kick two big dents into his.

title: Covid-19 and the Right to Travel
summary: Bans and quarantines are constitutionally suspect when applied against U.S. citizens.. President Biden has followed President Trump's lead in attempting to use international travel bans to reduce the spread of Covid-19. But Mr. Biden is reportedly considering an expansion of the policy. U.S. citizens, permanent residents and their immediate relatives are all exempt from existing travel bans.

title: Quarles Says Fed Will Need to Raise Rates to Cool Inflation
summary: The Fed governor says a new diagnosis of recent price pressures is warranted. A top Federal Reserve official said it was time for the central bank to prepare to raise interest rates because inflation was likely to stay above the Fed's 2% target for longer than anticipated.

title: 9 Unusually Satisfying Ways to See the Northern Lights
summary: Catching the elusive aurora borealis is always a gamble. We've zeroed in on nine prime sighting spots paired with diverting ways to take in the show, from atop a chairlift in Sweden to a photo expedition in Alaska.. LIKE CATCHING sight of a double rainbow, a breaching whale, or an available electrical outlet in an airport gate, the northern lights are an elusive but memorable quarry for travelers. The luminous swirls and waves of color that shimmer overhead are created when atomic particles ejected by the sun collide with atoms in Earth's atmosphere. The frequency and intensity of these celestial displays is cyclical, peaking at the "solar maximum," every 11 years (the next one will be in 2025.) Since the opposite, the placid "solar minimum," last occurred in 2019, this winter will probably provide better shows than any in the past few years and the next few winters have the potential to outshine this one.

title: Businesses Offer Higher Wages, but Who Will Accept Them?
summary: Latest NFIB employment survey shows a continuing labor shortage.. The drum-tight U.S. labor market continues to set records, as rising compensation at small firms still hasn't enticed enough workers to fill open positions. That's according to the November employment report from the National Federation of Independent Business, due out later today.

title: Kroger Sales Rise as Consumers Stay Home to Eat
summary: Company raises full-year guidance, but says higher supply-chain costs are hurting its profit. Kroger Co. reported strong sales for the latest quarter as consumers continued to opt for eating at home, but said higher supply-chain costs are squeezing its profit.

WASHINGTON-The Biden administration has reached an agreement with Mexico to restart a controversial Trump-era immigration policy known as Remain in Mexico, officials said Thursday. It expects to begin sending migrants back to the country beginning on Monday while their asylum claims are considered.

title: How to Turn an Idle Fireplace Into a Decor Showstopper
summary: Artful and inventive ways to make the most of a nonworking-or summering-hearth, courtesy of design pros. WHAT TO DO with a fireplace that's purely decorative or is sitting idle in the offseason? It's unfortunately a perfect place to house a cliché-birch logs, five fat candles, that inane books-turned-bindings-in trick. Jesse Carrier, of New York's Carrier and Company, is more optimistic: "The fireplace is an architectural focal point in a room, a wonderful stage to set with accessories and mementos that tell your story." He and other interior designers shared fresh ideas for sparking a room's black hole, whether a fireplace that doesn't work at all or one that's just enjoying the summer off.

title: Whether Omicron Wreaks Havoc or Not, the U.S. Dollar Is a Buy
summary: The greenback should do well if the economy shrugs off the new Covid-19 variant, or serve as a haven if it doesn't. Nothing is certain when it comes to how the Omicron variant of Covid-19 will affect economic growth, inflation and interest rates. Nothing, perhaps, except the value of the greenback.

title: Credit-Card Applications Hit Pandemic High
summary: Almost 27% of U.S. consumers said in October that they had applied for a credit card in the past 12 months. Americans are applying for credit cards at a rate not seen since before the pandemic.

title: Learn the Lesson of War in Vietnam-or Korea?
summary: In Southeast Asia and Afghanistan, U.S. unwillingness to expand the war led to defeat.. Regarding Arnold Punaro's op-ed "America Repeated Vietnam's Mistakes in Afghanistan" (Nov. 24): America was defeated in Vietnam and Afghanistan for a simple reason: It's next to impossible to win when your adversary has a safe harbor in an adjacent country. In Vietnam, we tried to deter the North Vietnamese by air power. This failed. In Afghanistan, we did little to deter the Pakistanis from providing the Taliban refuge and weapons.

title: No Excuse for the New Non-Covid School Closures
summary: Abrupt returns to virtual instruction have spread rapidly across the U.S.. As the authors of a recent article on the effect of prolonged educational disruption on children and adolescents, we'd like to emphasize the critical warning from Dr. Leslie Bienen in her op-ed "School Closures Aren't Just for Covid Anymore" (Nov. 29).

title: Walter Kirn Replies to Harper's: 'It's News to Me'
summary: None of the issues the magazine's publisher mentions were brought up during the dismissal call.. John R. MacArthur's account of why my contract was not renewed at Harper's (Letters, Dec. 1) is news to me. I have only the very brief phone call from the managing editor, Ellen Rosenbush-in which Mr. MacArthur did not participate-to go on. As I said to the Journal's interviewer ("The Weekend Interview With Walter Kirn" by Tunku Varadarajan, Nov. 27), no conversation was permitted in the call. Its tone was decidedly chilly and none of the issues with my performance that Mr. MacArthur brings up were mentioned. Also, in point of fact, I wrote only one column, not two, as he states, after the column that drew readers' ire, as evidenced by several negative letters the magazine chose to publish.

title: Ignore Short-Run Volatility and Reap Dow One Million
summary: Stocks don't go straight up.. In his Dec. 1 letter, Russell Wild writes that my op-ed "Get Ready for Dow One Million" (Nov. 3), published when the index exceeded 36,000, somehow jinxed the stock market because the Dow has since declined. I know that Mr. Wild is half-kidding, but I don't want to pass up this teachable moment. The lesson is this: Stocks don't go straight up!

title: Econ 101 for President Biden on Fossil Fuels
summary: When demand exceeds supply, prices go up; it's basic economics.. Rather than asking the Federal Trade Commission to examine price gouging, President Biden should ask himself why has he shut down pipelines, stopped drilling and increased regulatory actions against fossil-fuel production ("President Calls for Inquiry Into Price of Gas," Page One, Nov. 18). The increase in demand as the country is allowed to return to normal after the pandemic lockdown was predictable. When demand exceeds supply, prices go up; it's basic economics. Mr. Biden is dealing with the fallout from his ideology-driven actions, nothing more. Big Government threats cannot overcome poor, shortsighted policy decisions.

title: No Cash Bail for the Violent, Rich or Poor
summary: Releasing an accused violent criminal should not depend on ability to post bond.. In "The Waukesha Rampage" (Review & Outlook, Nov. 23), the editorial board asks, "Why was someone with that violent history released on such a minor bond?" Releasing an accused violent criminal should not depend on the criminal's ability to post bond. In that regard, the proponents of bail reform are correct. Poor violent offenders should receive the same treatment as rich ones.

title: Pittsburgh Steelers Co-Owner Stirs up Debate With Idaho Land Grab
summary: Billionaire Thomas Tull is buying up thousands of acres in Teton Valley, including a ranch formerly owned by Microsoft's Paul Allen. Pristine wilderness may no longer exist in the United States, but Idaho's Teton Valley comes close.

ISTANBUL-Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan named a loyalist as the country's new finance minister Thursday, after the incumbent resigned after clashes over the longtime leader's unconventional economic policies that have intensified a currency crisis.

title: China Protests 'Politicization of Sports'
summary: Women's Tennis Association earlier made good on threats to halt its events in the country amid concerns over the safety of star player Peng Shuai. Chinese authorities protested the departure of international women's tennis amid concerns over the safety of star player Peng Shuai, while at the same time moving to suffocate a brief flurry of online chatter about the news.

title: Roe v. Wade Made Viability the Key to Abortion Law
summary: A half-century ago, science and legal precedent led the Supreme Court to make fetal viability the standard in abortion law. On Wednesday, the Supreme Court heard oral arguments in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, a case centering on a Mississippi law that bans abortion after 15 weeks except "in medical emergencies or for severe fetal abnormality." The case raises a crucial question: Can states ban abortion before the point, at roughly 23 weeks, when the fetus is "viable"-that is, able to survive outside the pregnant woman's body? If the court answers yes, it could overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion until viability.

title: Pandas Face New Rival for Goodwill Ambassador: Pangolins
summary: Resume Subscription. TAIPEI-In the arena of animal diplomacy, Taiwan's scaly, long-snouted, ant-and-termite-eating pangolin is taking on China's cuddly panda.

title: The Swedish Hitmaker Behind Britney Spears, Taylor Swift and the Weeknd
summary: Resume Subscription. A 50-year-old failed rock singer from the suburbs of Stockholm is on track to become the No. 1 pop-music producer of all time.

title: Blackstone's Tony James to Retire
summary: In his nearly 20 years at the private-equity firm, James helped CEO Stephen Schwarzman shape the business into an investment giant. Hamilton "Tony" James, who helped transform Blackstone Inc. from a small private-equity shop into an investment giant with $731 billion in assets across numerous business lines, is leaving the company.

title: HSBC, Credit Suisse, Others Fined for 'Sterling Lads' Currency Cartel
summary: European Union imposes collective penalties of around $400 million on the banks. European Union authorities fined four banks close to $400 million for manipulating the foreign-currency market by exchanging sensitive information and trading plans, including through an online chat room dubbed "Sterling Lads."

title: Glaxo Says Antibody Drug Is Likely Effective Against Omicron
summary: U.K. drugmaker and partner Vir say treatment is designed to cope with mutations. Early laboratory studies suggest that a Covid-19 antibody treatment developed by GlaxoSmithKline PLC and Vir Biotechnology Inc. is effective against the Omicron variant, the companies said, setting it apart from similar therapies that appear to work less well against the highly mutated strain.

title: Everything Worth the Splurge During the Holidays
summary: From a book chronicling the construction of the Yves Saint Laurent museum to a new Vacheron Constantin timepiece, here's everything you should be thinking about buying this month.. Chanel's celebrated No. 5 fragrance inspires a playful brooch and other jewels.

title: Apollo to Buy Griffin Capital Units
summary: Deal will add about $5 billion of assets under management in products designed for individual investors. Apollo Global Management Inc. has agreed to buy the U.S. wealth-distribution and asset-management businesses of Griffin Capital Co., marking a big step in the investment giant's plan to expand its offerings for wealthy individuals.

title: The Buzziest Slice of London's Nightlife Comes to the Upper East Side
summary: Where Prince Harry dined and Rita Ora flouted Boris Johnson's lockdown rules: Casa Cruz is a West London hot spot now opening a six-story satellite on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Business partners Charlotte Santo Domingo and Juan Santa Cruz open the door.. For me, it's like being a movie director," says restaurateur Juan Santa Cruz of his experience at his London hot spots, Casa Cruz and Isabel. "I have the ability to transform your experience or your moment by controlling every single aspect of what you see, you feel, you hear, you smell and you taste," he says. "The only thing that you are in charge of is your conversation and your energy."

title: Russia Expels U.S. Diplomats in Latest Tit-for-Tat Action
summary: Moscow indicates that the move was in retaliation for Washington's expulsion of more than 50 Russian diplomats. Russia ordered U.S. Embassy staff who have been in Moscow for more than three years to leave the country by Jan. 31, a move that comes a day before diplomats hold talks to address the worsening relationship between the two countries.

title: As Covid-19 Drags On, Americans Hoard Cash
summary: Concern about the lingering pandemic has made many reluctant to dip into their funds. Americans are hoarding cash because of fatigue and uncertainty, with little chance the trend will reverse soon.

title: David Steinberger-Led Group Buys Ebook Publisher Open Road
summary: Open Road's catalog includes classics such as 'The Color Purple' and 'The Confessions of Nat Turner'. A group led by publishing veteran David Steinberger has acquired Open Road Integrated Media Inc., one of the country's first independent ebook publishers, the company and Mr. Steinberger said.

title: Wages Are Going Gangbusters in the U.S.-Elsewhere, Not So Much
summary: Resume Subscription. Yoichi Akimoto's pay has barely grown since he joined a Tokyo apparel company five years ago. He isn't expecting that to change, even as wages accelerate elsewhere in the world.

title: Investors Say Drug-Pricing Measure May Shift Incentives for Biotech Venture Funding
summary: Some analysts say bill would discourage investment in drugs taken as pills.

title: Chips Stacked High at GlobalFoundries
summary: Newly public chip manufacturer looks richly valued, but large base of noncancelable orders offsets risk. It's a good time to be a chip maker. Any kind of chip maker.

title: Holiday Crowds Flock Back to New York City
summary: Foot traffic and sales are meeting or exceeding pre-Covid-19 levels, retailers say. The heart of New York City is once again bustling with holiday crowds a year after a spike in Covid-19 infections kept visitors away.

title: The Scramble for EV Battery Metals Is Just Beginning
summary: Global miners have an opportunity to sell ESG-friendly natural resources to the automotive and energy industries, but it will require investment. Making the global economy more environmentally sustainable will require a lot more natural resources. This is an irony the mining industry will need both to exploit and to defuse.

title: Green Power Purchases Shielded Some Companies From Energy Crunch
summary: Long-term renewable-energy supply agreements can offer protection from price shocks, but they have gotten more expensive this year. More companies have been locking in long-term supplies of renewable energy in recent years as a way to cut greenhouse-gas emissions. For some, the deals offered another benefit in 2021: protection from higher prices as a surge in demand scrambled energy markets.

title: Renewable Natural Gas Firm Opal Fuels to Go Public in $2 Billion SPAC Merger
summary: Opal Fuels recovers methane from landfills and dairy farms to make a diesel-fuel alternative; it is combining with blank-check firm ArcLight Clean Transition II. Renewable natural-gas producer Opal Fuels LLC is merging with a special-purpose acquisition company to go public with a valuation of roughly $2 billion, the companies said.

title: What Is Cryptocurrency, and How Does It Work?
summary: We answer some commonly asked questions about this hot, but little understood, asset. Cryptocurrencies have become an investing mania again, which means-because I cover the topic for The Wall Street Journal-I field questions from a lot of people I don't usually hear from. Most recently, a high-school friend I haven't talked to in years pinged me. He has started investing in cryptocurrencies, but was looking for some guidance.

title: Digital Yuan Faces Obstacles in Winning Hearts and Minds
summary: Resume Subscription. China has convinced financial policy makers everywhere of its resolve to create a digital version of its currency, even helping to spur the Federal Reserve to study developing an electronic version of the dollar.

title: FAA Chief Steve Dickson Takes On Fight Over 5G and Aviation Safety
summary: Cautious regulator is at odds with telecom industry ahead of next month's planned rollout of new wireless services. In the battle over new 5G wireless service and aviation safety, a decision that could disrupt U.S. air travel will come down to a regulator known for methodical reviews and a cautious streak.

title: Illinois Abortion Clinics Are Preparing for a Potential Post-Roe World
summary: Resume Subscription. As the Supreme Court weighs a case that could chip away at federal abortion protections under Roe v. Wade, providers in Illinois are preparing for a potential surge of patients.

title: Women's Tennis Suspends Events in China Following Allegation Against Government Official
summary: Organization's chief executive expresses 'serious doubts' about the safety of Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis player at the center of global concern over her well-being. The Women's Tennis Association said Wednesday that it would halt all of its tournaments in China because it isn't satisfied that Chinese tennis player Peng Shuai is safe following an allegation of sexual assault against a retired senior government official made last month on her verified social-media account.

title: Australia Adopts Magnitsky Sanctions Rules
summary: Move brings Australia's sanctions rules in line with those of the U.S., as the two nations deepen ties. Australia passed new rules Thursday that will make it easier to sanction accused human-rights abusers, becoming the latest U.S. ally to pass a law styled after the U.S. Magnitsky Act.

title: U.S. and South Korea to Update Wartime Plans for North Korea
summary: In recent months, the Kim Jong Un regime has unleashed smaller-range weapons tests. SEOUL-The U.S. and South Korea said they would update their joint wartime contingency plans for North Korea, as the Kim Jong Un regime has kept pursuing military advances amid a stall in nuclear talks.

title: WeWork to Restate Results Due to Error With Its SPAC Acquirer
summary: Office-sharing company went public in October through a combination with BowX Acquisition Corp.. WeWork Inc. said in a securities filing that it would restate several quarters of its results, including its latest one, and that management has concluded there was a material weakness in its internal control.

title: MLB Braces for Lockout After Contract Talks End
summary: Discussions failed to yield a new collective bargaining agreement, setting the stage for the sport's first work stoppage since the 1994 season. Major League Baseball team owners have locked out the players in a battle over the game's future economic structure, initiating the sport's first work stoppage since the strike that resulted in the cancelation of the 1994 World Series.

title: Macau Casinos Shut High-Roller Rooms Tied to Arrested Operator
summary: Suncity Chairman Alvin Chau resigns, casino shares tumble again. HONG KONG-Macau's casinos have shut down the VIP rooms of the city's largest junket operator, and its leader, Alvin Chau, has resigned following his arrest on illegal gambling and money-laundering allegations.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Symone Sanders, Top Aide to Vice President Kamala Harris, to Leave Team
summary: She is the second senior staffer to announce a departure from the White House. Symone Sanders, senior adviser and chief spokeswoman to Vice President Kamala Harris, is planning to leave the White House at the end of the year, a White House official said.

title: Pelosi and Florida
summary: Whenever it's time to hand over the gavel, why not head to the Sunshine State?. A popular online rumor holding that Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) has bought a beachfront mansion in taxpayer-friendly Florida appears to be false. But that doesn't mean Mrs. Pelosi should rule out a move southward whenever she gives up the speaker's gavel, perhaps in January of 2023. A burgeoning effort by Sen. Bernie Sanders (Socialist, Vt.) to negotiate tax relief for well-heeled property owners like himself won't necessarily help the much wealthier Pelosi household. Also, a new report makes a strong economic case for a Pelosi escape to the Sunshine State.

title: Chris Cuomo Addresses CNN Suspension, Saying 'It Hurts'
summary: Anchor says he respects the process under way at the cable news network during his Sirius XM radio show. CNN anchor Chris Cuomo said being suspended by the network was embarrassing, addressing the controversy over his role in the sexual-harassment scandal involving his brother, former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, for the first time since the network took him off the air.

title: Hackers Breach Los Angeles Planned Parenthood Network
summary: Healthcare provider says more than 400,000 patients' records compromised. Planned Parenthood Los Angeles said it is investigating a cyberattack that compromised the personal information of thousands of patients.

title: Jan. 6 Panel Urges Contempt Charge for Jeffrey Clark
summary: House committee says former Justice Department official failed to comply with subpoena for testimony, documents on Capitol attack. WASHINGTON-The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol voted to recommend holding former Justice Department official Jeffrey Clark in criminal contempt for failing to comply with a congressional subpoena.

title: Justice Department Officials Dig In on Corporate Repeat Offenders
summary: Defense lawyers questioned the practicality of reviewing a corporation's entire rap sheet when resolving new misconduct, but Justice Department officials defended the practice. Companies looking to resolve with the Justice Department criminal violations such as bribery should prepare for a very thorough review of their prior sins, officials said Wednesday.

title: Snowflake Revenue More Than Doubles
summary: The data-cloud company, backed by Warren Buffett, says unanticipated business drove performance. Snowflake Inc.'s revenue more than doubled in the latest period and the cloud-computing-services company issued a bullish outlook, cheering investors.

title: Deterring Russia in Ukraine
summary: Vladimir Putin is probing to see if the U.S. really would push back.. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Wednesday made the toughest statements to date about Russia's military buildup on its border with Ukraine. And on Thursday he'll meet his Russian counterpart in Stockholm as tensions rise between Moscow and the U.S. The question is whether President Biden's envoy can convince Vladimir Putin that the U.S. means what it says.

title: Justice Sotomayor Gets Political on Abortion
summary: She loses her cool during the Supreme Court's oral argument.. The Supreme Court held a fascinating discussion on rights in the Constitution and when to overturn its own precedents on Wednesday in the oral argument on Mississippi's ban on abortion after 15 weeks (Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization). The media consensus is that a majority is prepared to alter its standard of review for abortion regulation by the states, though you never know for sure based on questions in oral arguments.

title: The Pentagon's Bureaucratic Posture Review
summary: A 10-month study reflects little strategic urgency about growing global threats.. Military planning in recent decades has increasingly become the purview of risk-averse academics and bureaucrats, and a new Pentagon study shows the result.

title: Mortgage Giant Fannie Mae Promotes Controller to Finance Chief
summary: Chryssa Halley joined the government-sponsored enterprise in 2006. Fannie Mae, the government-sponsored enterprise that guarantees mortgage loans, has promoted Chryssa Halley, from controller to chief financial officer.
